Dear Derek,

Thank you so much for your kind help, I will start reading the papers
you suggested and try using them and will inform you and the group of my
progress. 

Please bear in mind that my exam will start in January so I have to
prepare for my exams. I don't think I will start coding AI part of my
project till early February.

If you or anyone interested I will gladly send my codes which is most of
preparations done before starting on AI.

Thanks once again Derek for kind help.

Cheers,
Ramin



>>> djames@... 12/03/05 11:03 PM >>>
On 12/3/05, Ramin Lessani <kcy42rl@...> wrote:
>
> I want to use NEAT for a board game (hex)to train neural network
> controlled roving eye. if any one can suggest how i can use ANJI
"Roving
> eye" part . I will be ever so  grateful or any  suggestions would be
> highly appreciated.

Hi Ramen,

If you haven't already, I'd suggest reading Ken's paper "Evolving a
Roving Eye for Go"

http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/keyword?stanley:gecco04

as well as our paper "Evolving a Neural Network Active Vision System
for Shape Discrimination".  The first describes Ken's approach to
applying a roving eye paradigm to small-board Go and scaling up to
slightly larger boards.  The second describes how our version of the
roving (or "floating") eye is implemented, at a fairly high level of
description.

Then you might want to poke around the code.  Here are the ANJI
javadocs:

http://anji.sourceforge.net/javadoc/index.html

All the stuff that handles the eye is in the com.anji.floatingeye
package.  Logic for playing ANNs against each other or against
hand-coded algorithms is in com.anji.tournament, and logic specific to
Tic-Tac-Toe is in com.anji.ttt.

We implemented the floating eye for scanning any 2D surface, but have
not yet applied it specifically to board games, although I'm going to
try to implement this for 9x9 Go next semester for my first-year
project, so please let me know how you're progressing.  Carrying on
the discussion through the list is probably a good idea, so that
others who might be working on similar issues can chime in or simply
reference the thread.

Derek
